headline.main: More Children Need a Free Breakfast, Lunch -- and Dinner

docs.abstract: The moribund economy has driven many middle-class families to apply for school lunch subsidies for the first time.
docs.snippet: The moribund economy has driven many middle-class families to apply for school lunch subsidies for the first time.

docs.lead_paragraph: "I never thought a program like this would apply to me and my kids." That's what parents in the Gates Chili school district outside  Rochester are telling Debbi Beauvais, who administers the school meals program there. In a front-page article on Wednesday, The Times reported that around Rochester and across the country, suburban poverty means that schools are finding themselves serving more free or low-cost lunches - and breakfasts. And last year, when the proportion of students who qualified for free or subsidized lunches in the Hickman Mills C-1 district of Kansas City, Mo., hit 80 percent, the school began offering a third meal after the end of classes, paid for by the state.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Y.M.C.A., one of the nation’s largest child-care providers, will offer fruits, vegetables and water for snacks, increase exercise time and limit video games.

headline.main: Y.M.C.A. Adopting Health Policies for Youth
headline.print_headline: Y.M.C.A. Adopting Health Policies for Youth

docs.abstract: Young Men's Christian Association, one of the nation’s largest child-care providers, will offer fruits, vegetables and water for snacks, increase exercise time and limit video games; guidelines grow out of discussions the YMCA has been having with Michelle Obama and the Partnership for a Healthier America, a nonprofit group dedicated to supporting the first lady's campaign to reduce childhood obesity.
docs.snippet: The Y.M.C.A., one of the nation’s largest child-care providers, will offer fruits, vegetables and water for snacks, increase exercise time and limit video games.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of students are receiving free or low-cost meals for the first time after their parents lost homes or jobs in the economic crisis.

headline.seo: Surge in Free School Lunches Reflects Economic Crisis
headline.main: Lines Grow Long for Free School Meals, Thanks to Economy
headline.print_headline: Line Grows Long For Free Meals At U.S. Schools

docs.abstract: Millions of American schoolchildren are receiving free or low-cost meals for the first time, as their parents lose jobs or homes due to economic crisis; number of students receiving subsidized lunches rose to 21 million in 2010-11 school year from 18 million in 2006-7; many families who now qualify were once solidly middle class.
docs.snippet: Millions of students are receiving free or low-cost meals for the first time after their parents lost homes or jobs in the economic crisis.

byline.contributor: Robbie Brown and Kimberley McGee contributed reporting.

docs.lead_paragraph: This dish bakes for an hour, but the fish is well insulated by chard, flavorful tomato sauce and wine.

headline.seo: Halibut, Chard and Potato Casserole — Recipes for Health

docs.snippet: This dish bakes for an hour, but the fish is well insulated by chard, flavorful tomato sauce and wine.

docs.news_desk: Dining In, Dining Out / Style Desk
docs.lead_paragraph: This is based on a comforting Majorcan dish that is traditionally made with hake, a fish that isn't as easy to find here as halibut or Arctic char, both of which I've used for the dish. Pacific halibut is the type that gets the Environmental Defense Fund's highest rating. Make sure to cover this tightly so the fish doesn't dry out. An hour seems like a long time to cook fish, but the fish is well insulated and won't dry out. 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
docs.snippet: This dish bakes for an hour, but the fish is well insulated by chard, flavorful tomato sauce and wine.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of 28,880 people showed that people who consumed too little sodium were at greater risk for heart problems than people who took in a moderate amount.

headline.seo: For Heart Health, Less Sodium Isn’t Always Better
headline.main: Patterns: Less Salt Isn’t Always Better for the Heart
headline.print_headline: Patterns: Less Salt Isn’t Always Better for the Heart

docs.abstract: Study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association finds people who consume too little sodium are at greater risk for heart problems than those who take in a moderate amount; study is co-authored by Evan R Myers of Duke University.
docs.snippet: A study of 28,880 people showed that people who consumed too little sodium were at greater risk for heart problems than people who took in a moderate amount.

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Low levels of the essential vitamin can bring on symptoms including muscle weakness, fatigue, shakiness, unsteady gait, incontinence, low blood pressure and depression.

headline.seo: Vitamin B12 Deficiency Can Cause Symptoms That Mimic Aging
headline.main: It Could Be Old Age, or It Could Be Low B12
headline.print_headline: It Could Be Old Age, or It Could Be Low B12

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column warns that people with vitamin B12 deficiency can exhibit host of symptoms normally associated with age-related maladies, including muscle weakness, fatigue and cognitive dysfunction.
docs.snippet: Low levels of the essential vitamin can bring on symptoms including muscle weakness, fatigue, shakiness, unsteady gait, incontinence, low blood pressure and depression.
